texts.shortText:
Very elongated with many whorls (hence the common name screw-shell), each whorl bearing a pair of ridges running up its centre (sometimes 3-5 ridges in lower whorls). Aperture small, operculum horny and with concentric rings. Colour usually brownish-grey, sometimes purplish, with paler flames.

Also readily recognized by its unusual habit of burying head-down in sandbanks, often occurring in large numbers in sheltered sites.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Northern Cape border to about East London.

Very common in sheltered sandbanks, particularly in sites such as in Langebaan Lagoon, Saldanha Bay, False Bay and Knysna Estuary, where it can occur in many hundreds per square meter. Lives completely buried head-down into the sediment. Two channels through the sand communicate with the surface and water is drawn down one of these to the gills, which filter out fine particles and transport these in a string of mucus to the mouth, where the mucus string is raked in by the delicate radula. Wastewater is then expelled up the other channel back to the surface.
Filter feeder, filtering water though the gills and transporting captured particles to the mouth along with a string of mucus.

In this family sexes are separate and fertilisation is internal. Females generally lay clusters of egg capsules attached to small stones, each capsule containing 6-20 eggs. These usually hatch within one week and develop as pelagic larvae, although in some species eggs only emerge as crawling larvae. Details of reproductive mode are not know for local species.

One of several screw-shells on the region, which can be distinguished by habitat, as well as shell structure. The Threaded screw-shell T. carinifera grows to a larger size (48mm), has a single spiral ridge running up each whorl and occurs singly among encrusting organisms attached to rocks. The Mottled screw-shell T. sanguinea has rounded whorls with many fine parallel ridges and is marked with reddish-brown streaks. It is much larger, up to 106 mm and buries in sand in deeper areas. The Zebra screw-shell T. declivis can be abundant in deeper sediments, reaches 100 mm and has dark brown bands around each whorl.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 182)

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 52).
